M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant’s actions and inaction breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment established by M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, which guarantees tenants the right to peaceful use of their property free from substantial interference caused by their landlord.

M.G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the damages sought are within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under M.G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the property that is the subject of this action is located in Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts.

M.G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Hot water is a basic necessity of habitable housing and is required under the implied warranty of habitability codified by M.G.L. c. 239, § 8A and further supported by Massachusetts health and safety regulations.

See *Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingw.raw_text: See *Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184, 199-200 (1973) (implied warranty of habitability includes essential utilities);
See *Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingw.proposition: Defendant’s failure to timely restore hot water constitutes negligence and/or unreasonable delay in addressing basic repair obligations, which Massachusetts law requires landlords to fulfill.
See *Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingw.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurring/dissenting opinion focusing on how to conceptualize the landlord’s obligations (implied warranty vs. implied agreement to meet code standards) and the interdependence of rent and repair duties. It does not specifically address hot water, essential utilities, or characterize delayed restoration of hot water as negligence. While it recognizes that landlords must comply with State Sanitary Code minimum standards for habitability, it does not itself establish the narrower proposition that failing to timely restore hot water is negligence or an unreasonable delay under Massachusetts law.
See *Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingw.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

*Fitz-Inn Auto Parks, Inc. v. Boston Edi.raw_text: *Fitz-Inn Auto Parks, Inc. v. Boston Edison Co.*, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 39 (landlord failure to repair interfering conditions constitutes breach)
*Fitz-Inn Auto Parks, Inc. v. Boston Edi.proposition: Defendant’s failure to timely restore hot water constitutes negligence and/or unreasonable delay in addressing basic repair obligations, which Massachusetts law requires landlords to fulfill.
*Fitz-Inn Auto Parks, Inc. v. Boston Edi.support_reasoning: This opinion is a premises-liability slip-and-fall case about a retail store’s duty to keep entrance areas reasonably safe. It does not involve a landlord–tenant relationship, basic habitability or repair obligations, or the restoration of utilities such as hot water. The holding concerns lack of evidence that the store had notice of hazardous conditions (sand, salt, water, coins), not any duty to timely repair or restore building services, so it does not support the cited proposition regarding landlords’ repair obligations or hot water restoration.
*Fitz-Inn Auto Parks, Inc. v. Boston Edi.relevant_excerpt: To establish Building 19’s negligence, the plaintiff was obligated to establish a breach of Building 19’s duty “to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.” ... The denial of Building 19’s motion for involuntary dismissal was error.
